title: Balaam and Balak
shortSummary: Numbers chapter 22 recounts the story of Balak, king of Moab, who seeks to hire the prophet Balaam to curse the Israelites. Despite Balak's persistent requests and offers of reward, Balaam obeys God's commands, leading to a dramatic encounter involving Balaam's donkey and the angel of the Lord. This chapter highlights God's sovereign protection over His people and the importance of obedience to His word.
timeline: c. 1445 BC - Israel's wilderness journey before entering Canaan

keyCharacters.name: Balak
keyCharacters.description: King of Moab who fears the Israelites and seeks to curse them through Balaam.

keyCharacters.name: Balaam
keyCharacters.description: A prophet from Pethor who is summoned by Balak to curse Israel but ultimately obeys God's instructions.

keyCharacters.name: Angel of the LORD
keyCharacters.description: A divine messenger who confronts Balaam on his journey to oppose him for disobedience.

keyCharacters.name: Ass (Donkey)
keyCharacters.description: Balaam's donkey who miraculously speaks to warn Balaam of the angel's presence.

definitions.definition: A solemn invocation of harm or misfortune upon someone, often used in the context of prophetic declarations.
The practice of seeking knowledge or guidance from supernatural sources, often associated with pagan rituals.
A special messenger from God who sometimes represents God's presence and authority.
The location near the Euphrates River where Balaam lived, known for its association with diviners.

outline.heading: Israel Camps Near Moab and Balak’s Fear
outline.description: The Israelites camp on the plains of Moab, causing fear among the Moabites. Balak, the Moabite king, perceives Israel as a threat and seeks a way to stop them.

outline.heading: Balak Sends for Balaam to Curse Israel
outline.description: Balak sends messengers to Balaam to curse Israel. Balaam consults God, who initially forbids him to go or curse Israel, affirming that the people are blessed.

outline.heading: Balak’s Renewed Request and God’s Permission
outline.description: Balak sends more honorable messengers with promises of reward. God permits Balaam to go but commands him to only speak what He instructs.

outline.heading: The Angel of the LORD Blocks Balaam’s Path
outline.description: On the journey, Balaam’s donkey sees the angel of the LORD and refuses to proceed, leading to a miraculous conversation. Balaam’s eyes are opened to see the angel, who warns him about his disobedience.

outline.heading: Balaam Meets Balak and Prepares to Curse
outline.description: Balaam arrives and meets Balak, emphasizing that he can only speak God’s word. Balak offers sacrifices and takes Balaam to a high place to view Israel.

application: Trust in God's sovereign protection even when circumstances seem threatening, as He blesses His people and thwarts evil plans.
Obedience to God's word must take precedence over personal gain or external pressure, as Balaam demonstrates.
Be attentive to God's warnings and correction, recognizing that He may use unexpected means to guide and protect us.
Speak only what God commands, remembering that true prophetic authority comes from Him alone.

keyVerses.text: And God said unto Balaam, Thou shalt not go with them; thou shalt not curse the people: for they are blessed.
keyVerses.significance: This verse reveals God's sovereign blessing on Israel and His command for Balaam to obey, underscoring the futility of opposing God's will.

keyVerses.text: And the LORD opened the mouth of the ass, and she said unto Balaam, What have I done unto thee, that thou hast smitten me these three times?
keyVerses.significance: This miraculous event highlights God's intervention to correct Balaam and emphasizes the seriousness of obedience to God.

keyVerses.text: And Balaam said unto Balak, Lo, I am come unto thee: have I now any power at all to say any thing? the word that God putteth in my mouth, that shall I speak.
keyVerses.significance: Balaam's declaration affirms that true prophetic authority is from God alone, not from human promises or pressure.
